Barisal.name: Barisal
Barisal.banner: Known as the 'Granary of Bengal' for its fertile lands.

zila.banner: Barishal city, nicknamed 'Venice of the East'.
zila.economy: Primarily agricultural (rice, jute), fisheries, and small-scale industries.
zila.education: Good literacy rate, home to Barishal University and numerous colleges.
zila.geography: Flat deltaic plain, crisscrossed by many rivers (Kirtonkhola, Arial Khan). Prone to tidal surges.
zila.history: Anciently known as Bakla-Chandradwip. Became Bakerganj district in 1797 under British rule. A major center of the Swadeshi movement. Barishal Division was established in 1993.
zila.name: Barisal

zila.banner: Largest island district of Bangladesh.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, betel leaf), fishing, and natural gas (Shahbazpur Gas Field).
zila.education: Developing, with primary and secondary schools, and some colleges.
zila.geography: A large deltaic island formed by the Meghna River's distributaries, vulnerable to cyclones and erosion.
zila.history: Part of the ancient Bakla kingdom. Elevated to a district in 1984. Witnessed devastating cyclones in 1970.
zila.name: Bhola

zila.banner: Known for its abundant natural resources and waterways.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, betel nut), fishing, and small businesses.
zila.education: Average literacy, with schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Low-lying deltaic area, with a network of rivers (Sugandha, Bishkhali) and canals.
zila.history: Part of the ancient Chandradwip kingdom. Became a subdivision of Barishal district in 1890 and a full district in 1984.
zila.name: Jhalokati

zila.banner: Home to Kuakata, 'Daughter of the Sea' for its panoramic sea view.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, pulses), fishing, and growing tourism due to Kuakata beach.
zila.education: Improving, with various educational institutions including Patuakhali Science and Technology University.
zila.geography: Coastal district in the southern part of Bangladesh, with the Bay of Bengal to its south. Prone to natural disasters.
zila.history: Once part of the Bakerganj district. Formed as a separate district in 1969.
zila.name: Patuakhali

zila.banner: Characterized by its dense network of rivers and canals.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, betel nut), fishing, and small cottage industries.
zila.education: Developing educational infrastructure.
zila.geography: A southern deltaic district, intersected by numerous rivers including the Baleshwar and Kocha. Part of the Sundarbans ecosystem.
zila.history: Part of the historical Bakla kingdom. Became a subdivision in 1875 and a district in 1984.
zila.name: Pirojpur

zila.banner: Southernmost district of Barishal Division, known for its coastal beauty.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, pulses), fishing, and some tourism potential (Kuakata adjacent areas, Fatrar Char).
zila.education: Growing educational facilities.
zila.geography: Coastal district bordered by the Bay of Bengal, with extensive mangrove forests and waterways.
zila.history: Part of the ancient Sundarbans area, gradually settled. Became a subdivision in 1969 and a district in 1984.
zila.name: Barguna

Chittagong.name: Chittagong
Chittagong.banner: The commercial capital and main seaport of Bangladesh.

zila.banner: Site of the largest seaport of Bangladesh.
zila.economy: Major industrial and commercial hub, export-import activities, garment industry, shipbuilding, and fishing.
zila.education: High literacy rate, home to University of Chittagong, Chittagong Medical College, and numerous other institutions.
zila.geography: Coastal district with hills to the east and the Bay of Bengal to the west. Crossed by rivers like Karnaphuli, Halda, and Sangu.
zila.history: Has a rich ancient history as a major port city. Ruled by various empires including Arakanese, Mughals, and British. Played a significant role in the Bangladesh Liberation War.
zila.name: Chittagong

zila.banner: The most remote and least populous hill district, known for its scenic beauty.
zila.economy: Agriculture (jhum cultivation, fruits), forestry, and increasing tourism (Boga Lake, Nilgiri, Sangu River).
zila.education: Lower literacy rate compared to plains, but efforts are ongoing to improve access.
zila.geography: Mountainous region, part of the Chittagong Hill Tracts, with dense forests, numerous small rivers, and waterfalls.
zila.history: Inhabited by various ethnic groups. Became a district in 1981, with a unique administrative system under the Hill District Councils.
zila.name: Bandarban

zila.banner: Known as the cultural capital of Bangladesh, with a rich heritage in music and literature.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute), natural gas, fisheries, and small industries (e.g., re-rolling mills).
zila.education: Good literacy, with numerous schools and colleges, including Brahmanbaria Medical College.
zila.geography: Mostly flat farmland, part of the Gangetic Plain, bounded by rivers like Meghna and Titas.
zila.history: Part of the ancient Samatata region. Was a subdivision of Cumilla (formerly Tripura) district. Became a separate district in 1984. Home to many nationalist leaders.
zila.name: Brahmanbaria

zila.banner: Famous as 'Hilsha City' for its abundance of Hilsha fish.
zila.economy: Fishing (especially Hilsha), agriculture (rice, jute), and riverine trade.
zila.education: Developing, with various educational institutions.
zila.geography: Deltaic plain at the confluence of the Meghna, Padma, and Dakatia rivers, making it a major river port.
zila.history: Part of greater Cumilla district. Established as a subdivision in 1878 and a district in 1984. Known for historical sites like Rasti Shah Dargah.
zila.name: Chandpur

zila.banner: Home to the world's longest natural sea beach (120 km).
zila.economy: Tourism, fishing, salt farming, and aquaculture.
zila.education: Developing, with a focus on vocational training related to tourism and fisheries.
zila.geography: Coastal district along the Bay of Bengal, with hills to the east. Prone to cyclones.
zila.history: Named after Captain Hiram Cox of the British East India Company. Was a subdivision of Chattogram district until it became a district in 1984.
zila.name: Cox's Bazar

zila.banner: Known for Mainamati archaeological site and BARD (Bangladesh Academy for Rural Development).
zila.economy: Primarily agriculture (rice, jute), cottage industries (Khadi textiles), and a growing export processing zone (CEPZ).
zila.education: High literacy, with Comilla University, Comilla Medical College, and many other institutions.
zila.geography: Located in the eastern part of Bangladesh, bordered by Tripura (India) to the east. Features include the Lalmai-Mainamati hills.
zila.history: Established as a district by the British in 1790 (then Tripura District). Renamed Cumilla in 2018. Site of ancient Buddhist monasteries.
zila.name: Cumilla

zila.banner: Gateway to southeastern Bangladesh, strategically located on the Dhakaâ€“Chittagong corridor.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice), small industries, and trade due to its strategic location.
zila.education: Developing educational infrastructure.
zila.geography: Coastal district in the southeast, characterized by the Feni River. Part of the larger Noakhali plains.
zila.history: Historically part of greater Noakhali, Cumilla, and Tripura. Became a subdivision in 1876 and a district in 1984. Named after the Feni River.
zila.name: Feni

zila.banner: One of the three hill districts, known for its scenic beauty and indigenous cultures.
zila.economy: Agriculture (jhum cultivation, fruits), forestry, and limited tourism.
zila.education: Lower literacy rate, efforts being made to improve access to education.
zila.geography: Hilly terrain, part of the Chittagong Hill Tracts, with valleys and forests. Crossed by the Chengi and Myani rivers.
zila.history: Inhabited by various ethnic groups. Became a subdivision in 1983 and a district in 1984, with a special administrative system.
zila.name: Khagrachari

zila.banner: A coastal district with a rich agricultural base.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute, betel nut), fishing, and some small industries.
zila.education: Growing educational facilities.
zila.geography: Low-lying coastal plain, influenced by the Meghna River and its distributaries. Prone to tidal floods.
zila.history: Part of the ancient Bhulua kingdom. Became a subdivision in 1979 and a district in 1984.
zila.name: Lakshmipur

zila.banner: Known for its unique Noakhali dialect and historical significance.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, betel leaf), fishing, and developing small and medium industries.
zila.education: Good literacy, with Noakhali Science and Technology University and various colleges.
zila.geography: Coastal district in the southeastern part of Bangladesh, heavily influenced by the Meghna estuary, leading to land erosion and accretion.
zila.history: Established as a district in 1821 (then Bhulua district). Played a significant role in the anti-colonial movements.
zila.name: Noakhali

zila.banner: The largest district in Bangladesh, characterized by its vast hills and lakes.
zila.economy: Agriculture (jhum cultivation, fruits), forestry, and hydropower (Kaptai Dam). Tourism is growing.
zila.education: Lower literacy rate, but with specific initiatives for indigenous communities.
zila.geography: Hilly region, part of the Chittagong Hill Tracts. Home to Kaptai Lake, the largest artificial lake in Bangladesh.
zila.history: Inhabited by various ethnic groups. Became a district in 1981, with a special administrative structure.
zila.name: Rangamati

Dhaka.name: Dhaka
Dhaka.banner: The capital city and largest metropolitan area of Bangladesh.

zila.banner: Bustling capital, center of politics, economy, and culture.
zila.economy: Dominant service sector, garments industry, finance, trade, and IT.
zila.education: Highest literacy rate, home to numerous public and private universities (Dhaka University, BUET, DUET, Jahangirnagar University, etc.), medical colleges, and schools.
zila.geography: Flat deltaic land, surrounded by rivers like Buriganga, Turag, and Dhaleshwari.
zila.history: Dates back to the 7th century, became the Mughal capital of Bengal in 1610 (Jahangirnagar). Developed as a major commercial center under British rule. Capital of Bangladesh since 1971.
zila.name: Dhaka

zila.banner: Known for its fertile agricultural lands and jute production.
zila.economy: Primarily agriculture (jute, rice, onion), some small-scale industries.
zila.education: Developing, with a medical college, government colleges, and schools.
zila.geography: Flat deltaic plain, crisscrossed by rivers like Padma, Arial Khan, and Kumar.
zila.history: Part of the ancient Vanga kingdom. Named after the Sufi saint Shah Fariduddin. Became a district in 1815. Home to poet Jasimuddin and Bir Shrestha Munshi Abdur Rouf.
zila.name: Faridpur

zila.banner: Industrial hub with a significant garment industry.
zila.economy: Large-scale industries (garments, textiles), agriculture (rice), and growing urbanization.
zila.education: Developing, with various universities (Gazipur Agricultural University, Islamic University of Technology), colleges, and vocational institutes.
zila.geography: Located north of Dhaka, with the Turag and Balu rivers flowing through it. Features like Bhawal National Park.
zila.history: Historically significant as a strategic region. Site of the first armed resistance during the Liberation War. Became a district in 1984.
zila.name: Gazipur

zila.banner: Birthplace of the Father of the Nation, Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute), fisheries, and small cottage industries.
zila.education: Home to Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman Science and Technology University and various other institutions.
zila.geography: Low-lying deltaic area, with numerous beels and haors. Connected by rivers like Madhumati and Garai.
zila.history: Part of ancient Bengal. Became a subdivision in 1937 and a district in 1984. Associated with the spread of Islam by Sufi saints.
zila.name: Gopalganj

zila.banner: Land of 'Haors' (wetlands) and home to President Md. Abdul Hamid.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice), fisheries, and a large number of migrant workers' remittances.
zila.education: Developing, with several colleges and schools.
zila.geography: Characterized by extensive wetlands (haors) in the north-eastern part, which flood during monsoon. Intersected by rivers like Meghna.
zila.history: Part of ancient Samatata. Became a subdivision in 1869 and a district in 1984. Known for historical figures and movements.
zila.name: Kishoreganj

zila.banner: Known for the origin of the Faraizi Movement.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute), and small cottage industries.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Deltaic plain, situated on the bank of the Arial Khan river. Prone to river erosion.
zila.history: Formerly part of Faridpur district. Became a subdivision in 1869 and a district in 1984. Birthplace of Haji Shariatullah, leader of the Faraizi Movement.
zila.name: Madaripur

zila.banner: Famous for its Balanda (a type of sweet) and a bridge over the Dhaleshwari River.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute, vegetables), small industries, and fishing.
zila.education: Growing educational infrastructure.
zila.geography: Flat plain, intersected by the Dhaleshwari, Kaliganga, and Jamuna rivers.
zila.history: Part of the ancient Vanga kingdom. Became a subdivision in 1781 and a district in 1984. Known for its rich cultural heritage.
zila.name: Manikganj

zila.banner: Historical center of ancient Bengal, known for its archaeological sites (Bikrampur).
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute, vegetables), fisheries, and some small industries.
zila.education: Developing, with a focus on vocational training.
zila.geography: Deltaic land, surrounded by rivers like Meghna, Padma, and Dhaleshwari. Prone to river erosion.
zila.history: Site of the ancient city of Bikrampur, a capital of Bengal. Has a rich archaeological heritage. Became a district in 1984.
zila.name: Munshiganj

zila.banner: Major industrial city, famous for jute mills and textile industries.
zila.economy: Industrial hub (jute, textiles, hosiery, dyeing), trade, and river transport.
zila.education: Good literacy, with numerous technical and general educational institutions.
zila.geography: Located near Dhaka, on the banks of the Shitalakshya River. A major river port.
zila.history: Developed as a significant industrial and commercial center during British rule, especially for jute trade. Became a district in 1984.
zila.name: Narayanganj

zila.banner: Known for its fertile land and significant agricultural production.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute, sugarcane, vegetables), and small cottage industries.
zila.education: Developing educational facilities.
zila.geography: Flat plain, traversed by the Meghna and Shitalakshya rivers.
zila.history: Part of the ancient Samatata region. Became a subdivision in 1980 and a district in 1984. Site of various historical battles.
zila.name: Narsingdi

zila.banner: Border district known for its 'Balakhana' (traditional houses) and historical sites.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute, sugarcane), and traditional crafts.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Located on the banks of the Padma River, prone to river erosion and char lands.
zila.history: Part of the ancient Vanga kingdom. Became a subdivision in 1871 and a district in 1984. Named after Rajaram Roy, a local zamindar.
zila.name: Rajbari

zila.banner: Known for its historical mosque, the
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute), fisheries, and small cottage industries.
zila.education: Developing educational infrastructure.
zila.geography: Low-lying deltaic area, traversed by the Padma and Arial Khan rivers. Prone to river erosion.
zila.history: Formerly part of Faridpur and Madaripur districts. Became a district in 1984. Named after Hazi Shariatullah.
zila.name: Shariatpur

zila.banner: Known for its handloom products and a rich cultural heritage.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute), handloom industry (saris), and diverse cottage industries.
zila.education: Good literacy, with Mawlana Bhashani Science and Technology University and many colleges.
zila.geography: Mostly flat plain, with the Jamuna River forming its western boundary. Features like Madhupur Tract.
zila.history: Part of ancient Samatata. Became a district in 1969. Known for its contribution to the Liberation War and for the Madhupur Sal Forest.
zila.name: Tangail

Khulna.name: Khulna
Khulna.banner: Khulna Division is the second largest of the eight divisions of Bangladesh. It has an area of 22,285 km2 (8,604 sq mi) and a population of 17,416,645 at the 2022 Bangladesh census (preliminary returns). Its headquarters and largest city is Khulna city in Khulna District.

zila.banner: Major industrial and port city, particularly known for jute and shipbuilding.
zila.economy: Industries (jute, newsprint, shipbuilding, fish processing), trade, and port activities (Mongla Port, though geographically in Bagerhat, serves Khulna).
zila.education: Good literacy, with Khulna University, Khulna University of Engineering & Technology (KUET), and medical colleges.
zila.geography: Low-lying deltaic region, intersected by numerous rivers like Rupsa and Bhairab. Close to the Sundarbans.
zila.history: Developed as an industrial center during British rule. Became a subdivision in 1882 and a district in 1884. Played a significant role in the Pakistan Movement and Liberation War.
zila.name: Khulna

zila.banner: Home to the Sixty Dome Mosque and a significant part of the Sundarbans.
zila.economy: Forestry (Sundarbans), fishing, agriculture (rice), and aquaculture (shrimp).
zila.education: Developing, with primary and secondary schools, and some colleges.
zila.geography: Southern coastal district, dominated by the Sundarbans mangrove forest. Intersected by many rivers and canals.
zila.history: Named after the Muslim saint Khan Jahan Ali, who established Khalifatabad (present-day Bagerhat) in the 15th century. Became a district in 1984.
zila.name: Bagerhat

zila.banner: Westernmost district of Bangladesh, sharing a border with India.
zila.economy: Primarily agriculture (rice, sugarcane, wheat), and some small industries (e.g., Carew & Co. sugar mill and distillery).
zila.education: Developing, with various educational institutions.
zila.geography: Flat plain, with the Mathabhanga and Bhairab rivers flowing through it. Borders West Bengal, India.
zila.history: Formerly part of Nadia district (India). Became a subdivision in 1845 and a district in 1984. Served as the first temporary capital of Bangladesh during the Liberation War.
zila.name: Chuadanga

zila.banner: Historical city known for its significant role in the indigo rebellion.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute), fisheries, and some industries (e.g., pharmaceuticals).
zila.education: Good literacy, with Jashore University of Science and Technology and various colleges.
zila.geography: Flat plain, with rivers like Bhairab, Chitra, and Mukteswari. Shares a border with India.
zila.history: One of the oldest districts of Bangladesh, formed in 1781. Witnessed the Sepoy Mutiny and Indigo Rebellion. Played a vital role in the Liberation War.
zila.name: Jashore

zila.banner: Known for its vibrant folk culture and traditional crafts.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute, sugarcane), and small cottage industries.
zila.education: Developing, with educational institutions.
zila.geography: Flat plain, intersected by rivers like Kumar, Chitra, and Gorai.
zila.history: Formerly part of Jessore district. Became a subdivision in 1879 and a district in 1984. Site of significant historical events.
zila.name: Jhenaidah

zila.banner: Famous for Lalon Shah's shrine and traditional handicrafts like  Kushtia  Shahi  Pitha
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute, sugarcane, tobacco), traditional industries (handloom, sugar mills), and tourism (Lalon Akhra).
zila.education: Home to Islamic University, Kushtia Medical College, and numerous colleges.
zila.geography: Located on the banks of the Padma and Gorai rivers. Flat plain with fertile soil.
zila.history: Developed as a commercial center during British rule. Became a subdivision in 1860 and a district in 1897. Associated with famous literary figures like Lalon Shah and Mir Mosharraf Hossain.
zila.name: Kushtia

zila.banner: Known for its rich cultural heritage and traditional music.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute), fisheries, and traditional crafts.
zila.education: Developing educational facilities.
zila.geography: Flat deltaic plain, intersected by rivers like Nabaganga and Garai.
zila.history: Formerly part of Jessore district. Became a subdivision in 1845 and a district in 1984. Associated with the spread of Vaishnavism.
zila.name: Magura

zila.banner: Smallest district of Bangladesh, known for its mangoes.
zila.economy: Agriculture (mangoes, rice, jute), and small industries.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Small, flat district bordering West Bengal, India. Rivers include Mathabhanga and Bhairab.
zila.history: Formerly part of Kushtia district. Became a subdivision in 1845 and a district in 1984. Site of the provisional government of Bangladesh during the Liberation War.
zila.name: Meherpur

zila.banner: Home to the renowned painter S.M. Sultan.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute), fisheries, and traditional crafts.
zila.education: Developing, with focus on fine arts and vocational training.
zila.geography: Low-lying deltaic plain, intersected by rivers like Chitra and Nabaganga.
zila.history: Formerly part of Jessore district. Became a subdivision in 1861 and a district in 1984. Known for its rural beauty and cultural heritage.
zila.name: Narail

zila.banner: Southernmost district of Khulna Division, gateway to the Sundarbans.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, shrimp farming), fisheries, and forestry (Sundarbans).
zila.education: Developing, with various educational institutions.
zila.geography: Coastal district in the southwest, bordering the Sundarbans and West Bengal, India. Rivers include Kopotaksha and Malancha.
zila.history: Formerly part of Jessore district. Became a subdivision in 1861 and a district in 1984. Site of important battles during the Liberation War.
zila.name: Satkhira

Mymensingh.name: Mymensingh
Mymensingh.banner: Newly formed division, rich in culture and agriculture.

zila.banner: Known for its 'Mymensingh Gitika' (folk ballads) and agricultural research.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute, maize), fisheries, and some small industries.
zila.education: Home to Bangladesh Agricultural University, Mymensingh Medical College, and numerous colleges.
zila.geography: Flat plain, with the Old Brahmaputra River flowing through it. Features like the Madhupur Tract.
zila.history: One of the largest districts during British rule, established in 1787. Significant center for the peasant movements. Became a division in 2015.
zila.name: Mymensingh

zila.banner: Known for its scenic beauty and the Brahmaputra River.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute, mustard), and some small industries.
zila.education: Developing, with various educational institutions.
zila.geography: Flat plain, located on the banks of the Brahmaputra River. Prone to floods.
zila.history: Formerly part of Mymensingh district. Became a subdivision in 1845 and a district in 1978. Site of various historical events.
zila.name: Jamalpur

zila.banner: Known for its natural beauty, including wetlands (haors) and hills.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, fish), fisheries (haor areas), and small cottage industries.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Located in the north-eastern part of Bangladesh, characterized by haors, rivers (Kangsha, Mogra), and some hills.
zila.history: Formerly part of Mymensingh district. Became a subdivision in 1882 and a district in 1984. Rich in folk culture.
zila.name: Netrokona

zila.banner: Known for its Garo hills and agricultural products.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, maize, ginger, turmeric), and forestry.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Hilly terrain to the north (Garo Hills), transitioning to plains in the south. Intersected by rivers like Kangsha and Brahmaputra.
zila.history: Formerly part of Mymensingh district. Became a subdivision in 1899 and a district in 1984. Home to the Garo ethnic group.
zila.name: Sherpur

Rajshahi.name: Rajshahi
Rajshahi.banner: Known as the 'Silk City' and 'Education City' of Bangladesh.

zila.banner: Famous for its silk industry, mangoes, and educational institutions.
zila.economy: Agriculture (mangoes, silk, rice), silk industry, and education.
zila.education: High literacy, home to Rajshahi University, Rajshahi Medical College, and many other institutions.
zila.geography: Flat plain, located on the banks of the Padma River. Fertile agricultural land.
zila.history: One of the oldest districts, established in 1772. Served as an administrative and educational hub during British rule. Significant role in the Liberation War.
zila.name: Rajshahi

zila.banner: Known as the 'Gate of North Bengal' and for its historical Mahasthangarh.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, vegetables), small and medium industries (e.g., agro-processing), and traditional crafts.
zila.education: Developing, with various colleges and schools.
zila.geography: Flat plain, with the Karatoya River flowing through it. Features like the Barind Tract.
zila.history: One of the oldest urban centers in Bangladesh (Mahasthangarh). Became a subdivision in 1821 and a district in 1823. Rich archaeological heritage.
zila.name: Bogura

zila.banner: Mango capital of Bangladesh, known for its delicious varieties.
zila.economy: Agriculture (mangoes being dominant), fisheries, and some small industries.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Located in the northwestern part of Bangladesh, bordered by India. Rivers include Ganges (Padma) and Mahananda.
zila.history: Formerly a subdivision of Malda district (India). Became a subdivision of Rajshahi district in 1947 and a separate district in 1984. Rich in historical sites from the ancient Gaur kingdom.
zila.name: Chapainawabganj

zila.banner: Agricultural hub, known for its rice production.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, wheat), and small agro-based industries.
zila.education: Developing, with various educational institutions.
zila.geography: Flat plain, part of the Barind Tract. Rivers include Atrai and Punarbhaba.
zila.history: Formerly part of Rajshahi and Bogura districts. Became a subdivision in 1882 and a district in 1984.
zila.name: Naogaon

zila.banner: Known for its traditional sweet  Kacha   Golla  and historical palaces.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, sugarcane), traditional sweetmeat industry, and some small industries.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Flat plain, with rivers like Atrai and Boral. Fertile agricultural land.
zila.history: Formerly part of Rajshahi district. Became a subdivision in 1845 and a district in 1984. Home to historical zamindar families and palaces.
zila.name: Natore

zila.banner: Known for the Hardinge Bridge and its agricultural output.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute, sugarcane), industries (sugar mills, paper mills), and traditional pottery.
zila.education: Developing, with various educational institutions.
zila.geography: Flat plain, located on the banks of the Padma and Jamuna rivers. Prone to river erosion.
zila.history: Formerly part of Rajshahi district. Became a subdivision in 1828 and a district in 1832. Known for its rich cultural heritage.
zila.name: Pabna

zila.banner: Center of the handloom industry in Bangladesh.
zila.economy: Handloom industry (saris, lungis), agriculture (rice, jute), and fisheries.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Flat plain, intersected by the Jamuna and Dhaleshwari rivers. Prone to floods.
zila.history: Formerly part of Pabna district. Became a subdivision in 1845 and a district in 1984. Known for its contribution to the handloom sector.
zila.name: Sirajganj

zila.banner: Smallest district in Rajshahi Division, known for its rice and potato production.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, potato, sugarcane), and some agro-based industries.
zila.education: Developing educational facilities.
zila.geography: Flat plain, with a relatively high land elevation. Rivers include Jamuna and Tulshiganga.
zila.history: Formerly part of Bogura district. Became a subdivision in 1982 and a district in 1984.
zila.name: Joypurhat

Rangpur.name: Rangpur
Rangpur.banner: Center of North Bengal, known for its tobacco and historical sites.

zila.banner: Divisional headquarters, known for its rich history and cultural heritage.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute, tobacco, potato), small and medium industries, and tobacco processing.
zila.education: Home to Begum Rokeya University, Rangpur Medical College, and various other colleges.
zila.geography: Flat plain, with rivers like Teesta, Ghaghot, and Jamuneshwari. Features like the Barind Tract in parts.
zila.history: One of the oldest districts of Bangladesh, established in 1772. Has a rich legacy of peasant movements and cultural figures.
zila.name: Rangpur

zila.banner: Known for its historical Kantajew Temple and the Teesta Barrage.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, wheat, potato), and some agro-based industries.
zila.education: Developing, with Dinajpur Medical College, Hajee Mohammad Danesh Science & Technology University, and numerous colleges.
zila.geography: Flat plain, with rivers like Atrai, Punarbhaba, and Tangon. Part of the Barind Tract.
zila.history: One of the oldest districts of British India, established in 1786. Rich archaeological and cultural heritage.
zila.name: Dinajpur

zila.banner: Known for its char lands (river islands) and traditional   Gamcha  (local towel).
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute), fisheries, and traditional weaving.
zila.education: Developing, with various educational institutions.
zila.geography: Dominated by the Jamuna and Brahmaputra rivers, with extensive char lands and flood-prone areas.
zila.history: Formerly part of Rangpur district. Became a subdivision in 1875 (as Bhabaniganj, renamed Gaibandha) and a district in 1984.
zila.name: Gaibandha

zila.banner: Known for its vast wetlands (haors) and the Brahmaputra River.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute), fisheries (especially in haor areas), and traditional crafts.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Dominated by the mighty Brahmaputra River and its distributaries, with many char lands and flood-prone areas.
zila.history: Formerly part of Rangpur district. Became a subdivision in 1875 and a district in 1984.
zila.name: Kurigram

zila.banner: Border district, known for its Teesta Barrage project.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, jute, tobacco), and some agro-based industries.
zila.education: Developing educational facilities.
zila.geography: Flat plain, with the Teesta River flowing through it. Shares a border with India.
zila.history: Formerly part of Rangpur district. Became a subdivision in 1871 and a district in 1984. Known for its historical significance.
zila.name: Lalmonirhat

zila.banner: Known for its traditional 'Nil' (indigo) cultivation in the past and fertile agricultural land.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, potato, maize), and some small industries.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Flat plain, with rivers like Jamuneshwari and Buritista. Part of the Barind Tract.
zila.history: Named after the indigo cultivation. Formerly part of Rangpur and Dinajpur districts. Became a subdivision in 1875 and a district in 1984.
zila.name: Nilphamari

zila.banner: Northernmost district of Bangladesh, known for its tea gardens.
zila.economy: Agriculture (tea, rice, ginger, turmeric), and small agro-based industries.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Hilly terrain to the north, gradually becoming flat plains in the south. Borders India (West Bengal). Rivers include Karatoya and Atrai.
zila.history: Formerly part of Dinajpur district. Became a subdivision in 1856 and a district in 1984. Known for its tea estates.
zila.name: Panchagarh

zila.banner: Known for its sugarcane production and traditional crafts.
zila.economy: Agriculture (rice, sugarcane, wheat), and traditional crafts.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Flat plain, with rivers like Kulik and Nagar. Borders India (West Bengal).
zila.history: Formerly part of Dinajpur district. Became a subdivision in 1860 and a district in 1984. Site of various historical events.
zila.name: Thakurgaon

Sylhet.name: Sylhet
Sylhet.banner: Land of tea gardens and spiritual heritage.

zila.banner: Famous for its tea gardens, holy shrines, and natural beauty.
zila.economy: Tea industry, agriculture (rice), natural gas, tourism, and remittances from abroad.
zila.education: High literacy, home to Shahjalal University of Science and Technology, Sylhet Medical College, and various other institutions.
zila.geography: Hilly terrain in the north and east, with a low-lying plain in the center (haors). Rivers include Surma and Kushiara.
zila.history: Anciently known as Srihatta. A major spiritual center due to the shrine of Hazrat Shah Jalal. Became a district in 1772 under British rule. Part of Assam until 1947.
zila.name: Sylhet

zila.banner: Known for its tea gardens and natural gas fields.
zila.economy: Tea industry, natural gas, agriculture (rice, pineapple), and some small industries.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Hilly terrain and plains, with wetlands (haors) in parts. Rivers include Kushiara and Barak.
zila.history: Formerly part of Sylhet district. Became a subdivision in 1878 and a district in 1984. Known for its role in the Battle of Sagarkandi during the Liberation War.
zila.name: Habiganj

zila.banner: Known as the 'Land of Tea' and for its beautiful lakes.
zila.economy: Tea industry, tourism (Lawachara National Park, Madhabkunda waterfall), agriculture (rice, pineapple), and natural gas.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Hilly terrain and plains, with wetlands (haors) and numerous tea gardens. Rivers include Manu and Dhalai.
zila.history: Formerly part of Sylhet district. Became a subdivision in 1852 and a district in 1984. Known for its natural beauty and diverse ethnic groups.
zila.name: Moulvibazar

zila.banner: Land of vast wetlands (haors) and a significant source of freshwater fish.
zila.economy: Fisheries (haor areas), agriculture (Boro rice), and traditional crafts.
zila.education: Developing, with various schools and colleges.
zila.geography: Dominated by vast wetlands (haors) that are submerged during monsoon. Rivers include Surma and Kushiara.
zila.history: Formerly part of Sylhet district. Became a subdivision in 1877 and a district in 1984. Known for its natural beauty and biodiversity.
zila.name: Sunamganj
